column2: BEWARE!, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I needlessly had a number of epidural injections w/Kenalog 40 in a short period of time, all because of a misdiagnosis. Realized after the damage was done that the manufacturer mandates against its use for epidural injections, also realized too late that I was given far too much of the stuff (200 mg over 6 weeks and Im under 100 lbs). The last injection was over 5 months ago and Im still suffering from debilitating side effects, namely non-stop pain in all extremities  particularly acute in my hands and feet, and extreme fatigue where Im exhausted all day and literally cant get up and move in the morning. The pain is unlike anything Ive ever experienced before and difficult to describe  a deep itching, electrical sort of sensation and aggravated by any movement (such as typing). It seems theres no end in sight to this. Ive consulted w/numerous doctors about this reaction and they either deny any connection to the injections or are clueless. The havoc corticosteroids can cause on the body is extraordinary. I appreciate that these meds help some people, but doctors are far too cavalier in dispensing/injecting them, are irresponsible in not warning patients about side effects, and oddly, seem completely uneducated themselves about the side effects of the very drugs they routinely administer. Or perhaps they are lying for liability purposes and out of greed . . . I dont know.

column2: kneejerk, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Extreme adverse reaction, unwanted side effects of flushing, fever, extreme fatigue, brain fog, weakness and general malaise over a week's period.  Be sure to disclose ANY health concerns before agreeing to take this drug and be certain to familiarize yourself with possible side effects as a result of taking this drug.  Ask your Dr. to discuss in detail the risk/benefit of taking this particular steroid against the risks and precautions.  Make certain you understand the dosage that is given to you.  Inquire as to options for more conservative steroids with less risk of complications or side effects.  See your primary health care provider as quickly as possible if you are not receiving an appropriate or satisfactory response to reported unexpected side effects and request a comprehensive health examination or physical.

column1: Joint Disease which may include Attacks of Acute Arthritis
column2: islandangel, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I have both bowel and joint problems. My rheumatologist suspects a Spondyloarthropathy type disease. Severe pain in sacorilliac joints and hips, coincides with irritable bowel issues for at least 10 years. Every 3 months I have been receiving intramuscular kenalog. It usually begins working by the 4th day. It seems to keep it in remission. However, as a 41 year old woman I cannot continue to take it. This time post injection, I noticed breaking out in a sweat, nausea, horrible flatulence and not feeling well. This time I have a horrible gastro colic like episode with putrid sulfuric like flatulence, diarrhea & pain in the right upper quadrant. I normally do not get this kind of gas ever, not even from spicy food. I don't feel well at all. GI is just observing for now and said clear liquids. No more kenalog if I can help it. Next step, Humira.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I was given a Kenalog inhaler around 1988 for seasonal allergies - lead to MS-like symptoms, muscle spasms/dystonia, mood fluxuations, allergic reactions increased & even bing maxed out on Benedryl didn't stop the reaction. Kenalog nearly put me in a wheelchair. My endocrinologist In 2010, I was given 4 sympathetic nerve blocks w/ Kenalog for RSD/CRPS of the R foot/leg (& possibly spreading?) Had a tear in R shoulder connective tissue that was inconsistent with slight jarring which was clearly inconsistent with the fall, but after antibiotic Tx which could explain that injury. After 2nd Tx, developed kidney stones/infection/pyrexia x 1 month. Generalized pain was increased post-op. Pain in L side (wondered if I'd coded in surgery & paddles had been used-neg.) After 4th block, now have bone pain in hips, neck, shoulders; extreme generalized pain, body-wide muscle wasting, vomiting, arrhythmia, chest pains w/ numbness of L arm, extreme photo-sensitivity & eyes burning(possibly other photo-sensitivity as well - can barely stand a 60w light bulb or dimmed computer screen), a few bouts of incontinence, possible seizures, bruising on legs & arms, sleeplessness & a drug-induced mania that lasted for days without sleep. I had increased intracranial pressure from a nasal inhaler around 1988 & likely far worse this time around.My hope is that this drug, as well as other corticosteroids, will be strongly regulated, with a requirement of patients being counseled on effects, side effects & possible adverse reactions & a requirement that patients sign off on any procedure at least 3 days before it is done with ANY corticosteroid use with full disclosure of any and all potential side & adverse effects. I had a prior reaction to this same drug & had there been this requirement, I would not be in the condition I am in now. A prior adverse reaction to steroids was overlooked and as a result. I hope OTC cortisone preparations become prescription only & more regulated than opiods.

I anticipate that the doctor will recommend knee replacement surgery on my next office visit.

column2: Just Jo, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: Diagosis: Spinal Stenosis  8/5/09 I received a Kenalog injection by a board certified anesthesiologist pain management specialist and was pain free for 6 months.  3/17/10 I received my 2nd Kenalog injection by the same physician and am still in the "take it very easy" post injection period.  Thus far for spinal stenosis I am very satisfied with this treatment.  I know others who have not had a good experience, however, their injections were not given by an anesthesiologist.  I will try to remember to update my results from the 3/17/10 procedure.  The process was simple, the physician and staff were highly qualified, personable, answered all questions pre and post injection.  I had to be driven to and from the center and they had to stay with me for an hour or so afterwards as a precaution for any adverse reaction.

column1: Allergic Reaction caused by a Drug

column9: Went to the Docter for severe seasonal allergies... eyes gushing water and post nasal drip that just would not stop.Antibiotics prescribed caused severe diarrhea. Now I have a "crater" at the injection site in my upper arm, and a sort of numbness in my entire arm, plus my monthly cycle is completely haywire. It seems to me like she used a sledge hammer to kill a fly. No Dr. should give a person this injection without letting you know the possible side effects so a person can make an informed choice. For me it was not worth it at all I got little or no relief from this shot. I'm extremely upset and disappointed that my Dr. made such a bad decision.

column1: Allergic Reaction caused by a Drug
column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I was given 40mg dose of Kenalog IM inj in my left arm to help alleiviate seasonal allergies. I only took the inj once and was given some oral pills called Loratadine along with the kenalog and felt fine. About three months later, i noticed a two by one inch deeply atrophied area around the inj site. I went to my doctor to find out if there was any meds or exercise i could do to regain muscle mass. He told me there was nothing i could do and that he had only read of this particular side effect. He had never seen it before on a patient. Yes the combined drugs helped my allergies but left me with a piece of my muscle gone and still experiencing more symptoms as time passes with the atrophy.  I highly recommend to all who read this to read up on any and all drugs your doctor tries to give you before they give it to you. I am nineteen years old and will always have a piece missing out of my arm and who knows if the atrophy is done spreading. No one told me this could possibly happen. I will be posting more if other symptoms present themselves.

column1: Joint Disease which may include Attacks of Acute Arthritis
column2: shelby7, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I had a fractured hip 20 years ago and since then the area around ball and socket has deteriorated badly and also have 3 spurs in joint area.  I am now 42 and recieved 12 injections over the last 5 years. They inject in the front groin area after numbing with lydocain under Xray to make sure they are in the correct area.  I don't like being sedated so I chose not to.  You can be knocked out for this but it only takes 15 minutes in-out time on table. Relief is wonderful, instantly when combined with marcaine.  I can't complain at all.  To list I did have some side effects afterwards like acid reflux, tenderness of muscle at site and insomnia the first few nights.  I expected these because before I chose to do this I read extensively the pros and cons.  I would like to comment on that part here.  I have read so many posts that says my doctor never told me this or that side effect.  Be prepared for side effects with any medication introduced into your body.  To not think that, your not doing your homework pertaining to YOUR body.  I understand all treatments do not work for everyone but I absolutely would of had a hip replacement 6 years ago at age 36.   I feel I bought,so far, 6 decent years of wear and tear on the artificial one.  I would recommend HIGHLY for people in my situation of severe joint pain especially of the hip.

column2: Alison, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have had ongoing bouts of granuloma annulare / actinic granuloma for a number of years now.  The most effective treatment has been extremely small amounts of Kenolog injected directly into the individual eruptions which present themselves, primarily, on sun-exposed skin.  This therapy is administered anywhere from every 30 to 90 days, dependent upon the severity of outbreaks.  I've tried PUVA light treatments, Accutane, Prednisone, Plaquinil, topical Clobetasol & Clobex without much success (Clobex lotion &/or spray gives some relief in specific areas...it will lessen the severity; eruptions decrease, yet slight discoloration remains & over time, skin texture roughens & after discontinuing, eruptions will reappear).  The only thing that has helped, so far, has been the Kenolog.  However, if too much is injected into one site, it causes bruising which may (or may not) eventually subside.  Oftentimes, there's nominal bleeding at some of the injection sites.  Another downfall to Kenalog injections for this ailment is that continual use causes the skin to thin, resulting in periodic petichiae & superficial veins to appear.  Bottom line: this therapy does work if administered by a knowledgeable & competent medical professional, yet only as a temporary fix for unsightliness & discomfort.  Ongoing treatment is required; thus, the positive results outweigh the bad points.  There's always a trade-off.

column1: Skin Disease Characterized by Swollen Itching Lesions

This was a painless injection with immediate results that just keeps getting better and better. Lesions have been so ugly and really embarassing. This was very exciting to have something actually work. I looked up the drug as was curious if it was a corticosteroid only to find out it's Triamcinolone. I was just prescribed that also (ointment) for my skin too and have loved the help that's also been.

After a nap, I feel better, but still feel a little jittery.  My pharmacist says my reaction is a rare side effect.  My doctor says she thinks it was caused by my illness brought on by the allergies.  I think the pharmacist is right. I feel so much better than yesterday, the temporary discomfort was worth it.  But, next year I will go back to Solu-Medrol.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months
column9: I received 2 Kenalog injections for a herniated disc. I was never told the side effects that could occur. I have had vision changes, mood swings, depression, weight gain, fluid retention, dizziness, migraines, and my hands have been shaking so bad that I could not do my job. I am a registered nurse and luckily I recognized the side effects from the steroid and asked the anestheologist about them. I was told that it rarely occurred. I also had to go to the emergency room a week after the second injection due to breathing difficulties. I would highly recommend talking with your doctor about the pros and cons of this steroid. It has changed who I am and I have to live with it every day. I am in my 20s and am unable to receive a third injection due to the breathing issue. My only other option is to have the surgery where they fuse the vertebrae together. And unfortunately with the second injection, they had to use less steroid due to the Cushing Synd side effects I was already having. The 2nd injection never really worked and I have had to suffer with the side effects.

column1: Inflammation of the Sac Surrounding the Joint - Bursitis
column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Was injected with 40mg Kenalog in my knee, the injection itself was excruciatingly painful. By the next day my knee had swollen up like a balloon. The joint was stiff and painful and have had an increase in pain instead of the relief that was expected.

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: A severe and prolonged allergic response to exposure to multiple known allergins.  A one time injection allowed relief and movement to a longer term plan.

column2: redrage, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I actually had my first injection for my arthritic right hip.  The next day I had a fever, my whole body ached, and a severe headache. I originally thought it was some bug or the flu.  But 3 months later I received another injection for an allergic reaction to poison ivy.  That's when I consulted my doctor and he said I was allergic to Kenalog.  It did make my hip feel better and it clear up my poison ivy.

column1: Inflammation of the Nose due to an Allergy

column9: when my allergies are extremely bad this is the only thing that works. the problem is my doctor will oinly give it to me every three months.

column1: Disease in which Body has Immune Response Against Itself
column2: parrotlov1@hotmail.com, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have  lupus/scleroderma and also DDD and a blugging disc, I have been given this medication through injections (nerve block) and have problems with rashes and hair falling out after a 80mg dose. not happy at all

column2: tuckertoo, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I received$ a Kenalog injection for chronic abdominal pain one week ago, and since then, my pain has risen to a 9 on a scale of 1-10. After the injection, I didn't know whether I had to pee, poop, or vomit. I felt like I was having a miscarriage. I couldn't talk without wanting to scream, walking was barely manageable. I called the surgeon back on Monday (the injection was on Thursday), and the comments I got were: "That isn't supposed to happen" and "She won't give you that shot again." I now must have an abdominal ultrasound, ordered by my primary, to determine if damage has been done, or if it's just a reaction. I am taking so much Percocet that I should be flying, but my pain level actually surpasses the pain killers.This has been one of the worst experiences of my life in terms of medical misfires.

column2: SBQ, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have received 2 kenelog inj. of 80mg each, 1 month apart in my epidural space for pain relief. I have Cushing's Syndrome now and I don't know if this is the cause and it will go away when/if this ever wears off, or if it exaserbated an already existing condition. but I have spent HOURS researching this! The first shot, I had 3 weeks of pain relief and the second, 5 weeks. Not worth it for the misery I'm in now if this is in fact the cause.I marked the ease of use as difficult only because I have to travel 1 1/2 hours to the hospital to get the injection done, then I need a driver to take me home.

column1: Inflammation of the Lining of a Joint
column2: Stentsguy1, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Warning. I was nnot aware that this medicine would cause a huge spike in my blood sugar. That effect has lasted about a week and I'm not returning to normal levels.

column2: 45-54 on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have severe seasonal allergies, this last time aggravating asthma, and this shot both in the past and this time has cleared it up! For me, it is a miracle drug.

column2: THALE, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I HAVE ALWAYS HAD BAD ALLERGIES AND ASTHMA SINCE I WAS LITTLE. I WENT TO AN ALLERGIST MOST OF MY LIFE, GETTING 2 SHOTS A WEEK IN BOTH ARMS. I WAS ALSO TAKING DIFFERENT MEDICINES WHICH DID'NT WORK VERY WELL. ONE DAY SOMEONE TOLD ME ABOUT KENALOG. I'VE GOTTEN THE SHOT FOR THE LAST 4 YEARS, JUST ONE TIME A YEAR. WHAT A MAJOR RELIEF IT WAS IN MY LIFE. I WOULD RECOMMEND IT TO ANYONE. THE ONLY THING I HEARD BAD ABOUT IT WAS IT HAD STEROIDS AND COULD CAUSE OSTEOPEROSIS. I'M NOT SURE HOW TRUE THAT IS?

column2: Gatorboy, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)

column1: Skin Rash that Becomes Thick &amp; Discolored From Rubbing It

column9: after the third injection my leg started hurting but my doctor said it wasn't from injections after the fourth injection my leg felt like i got insect bite it develop very quickly into pose filled rash and very painful with nothing helping the pain it feels like a burn and its been over a month and its still draining and hurts. all the surgeon tells me is that it has to come out my system.

column1: Joint Disease which may include Attacks of Acute Arthritis
column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: The injection gave me relief of pain from degenerative joint disease of my right hip. I am able to move about as normal.  Two years ago this was unsuccessful with my left hip because the disease process had progressed too far.  I eventually had a total left hip replacement.  The injection in my right hip is giving me more time before the eventual replacement of my right hip. My orthopaedic surgeon administered the injection by flouroscopy.

column2: Corners, 55-64 Male  (Patient)
column9: I told my Doc. that I was allergic to this this medication.  Still he gave me a small shot on the forearm as a test site.  It turned the injection site into a white, round circle and is now going up my arm.  I now am having "red" spots around the injection site and also going up the arm.  These red spots are now bleeding and won't stop bleeding until I put a lot of pressure on them and use a bandaid, stuck on very tight.  I am going to speak to an attorney about it.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Although I have been cleared of my allergies, the injection has left me with an irregular menstrual cycle wreaking havoc on my mood and body. I have never been irregular before, and at 34 (with 2 children) never thought I would be until maybe menopause - but I was informed by my gynecologist that this could happen - and it did to me. I have had 4 menstrual cycles in the last 8 weeks. It has been miserable, and the doctor said it could take 3 months to clear up. Not worth it!!! I will gladly take a sudafed everyday that have to endure the inconvenience and the moodiness. My poor husband:) Just thought everyone should know that this side effect is out there for this drug. I have since talked to a friend, and the SAME thing happened to her. Just be warned!

column2: 25-34 Female  (Patient)
column9: I'm so glad my doctor offers this option for me when I'm unresponsive to other medications.  For some reason my asthma responds best to cortisone, and kenalog is a great option for long lasting relief

column2: andy1967@embarqmail.com, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: From July 2007 to the present I have had a constant dry cough, symptoms of sinus infection, alot of throat congestion and mild chest congestion with tightness in the chest.  I went to the emergency room numerous times and I was mostly treated for upper respiratory issues. On two occasions  I was given this drug (either Kenalog inj or kenalog 40 inj, I don't know) in the emergency room on 2 different occasions.  The first time that I was given the drug, I was given a shot that contained one dose.  The next day I noticed that tightness in my throat was gone and no cough and no side effects.  The next time that I was given this drug, the doctor gave me 5 doses in one shot.  He also gave me a shot of Ativan (probably 2mg) in the same visit. Moments after, I became very confused.  It was hard to think.  When I would talk, no one could understand what I was saying.  I didn't know what I was saying.  I couldn't read or write or spell.  I went to another hospital and they did a bunch of tests and kept me overnight for observation.  The effects did wear off by sometime the next day.  I am convinced that I had an overdose of this drug. If any doctors read this, please tell me what you think.  This was very scary. Additionally, my symptoms are still with me.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: This is the only treatment that cleared up my allergies. I tried over the counter medications and nothing helped as well as Kenalog. I have taken one Kenalog shot per year and it clears me up by the next day for a full year.
